article.description: Freshman Dee Brown scored 25 points -- including 12 of 19 as Illinois took control early in the second half -- and Brian Cook added 21 as the Illini (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 15 AP) beat Eastern Illinois 80-68 Tuesday night.
article.headline: Freshman Brown makes sure Illini stay unbeaten
article.linkText: Freshman Brown scores 25 points in Illinois' victory
article.story: CHAMPAIGN, Ill. (AP) -- After playing three games in a week, including a win over nationally ranked North Carolina, Illinois (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 15 AP) didn't seem all that interested against lowly Eastern Illinois. ''It seems like we botched some real easy plays,'' Illini coach Bill Self said after Tuesday's 80-68 victory. ''And all of a sudden the collar gets tight and we get passive. We were probably a little flat.'' The Illini (6-0), off to their best start since the 1995-96 season when they opened 9-0, led 38-32 at halftime but turned the energy up after that. Freshman Dee Brown scored 12 of 19 points as Illinois took control early in the second half. Brown led Illinois with 25 points. ''Coach really got on me in the locker room,'' Brown said. Brown scored 20 points after halftime, hitting 4-of-6 from behind the arc and electrifying the crowd on several fast-break layups. ''It all starts with me on defense,'' Brown said. ''I pressure the ball (and) get into my comfort zone. It livens up my teammates and the crowd.'' With Brown hitting his shots, intercepting Panthers passes, and taking care of the ball, the Illini pushed the lead to as many as 24 points before a late run by Eastern cut into it late. Illinois had seven steals in the final 20 minutes and shot 59 percent after halftime. ''I think Dee keys everything,'' Self said. ''I don't think Dee played with much energy in the first half. He had two fouls and sat on the bench and never got in the flow. I thought he played with a lot more energy defensively in the second half.'' The Illini led by four points early in the second half, when they took advantage of six turnovers by Eastern Illinois (3-5) to extend their lead to 15 points. Brown had two 3-pointers during the surge, and was 5-of-8 from beyond the arc and 10-of-14 overall. ''What you have to like about Dee is he's quick as lightning, but always under control,'' Eastern coach Rick Samuels said. ''He has to be fun to play with.'' Henry Domercant, the nation's eighth-leading scorer at 25 points per game, had 30 for the Panthers. Domercant scored 14 points in the first 20 minutes, but went scoreless during a 10-minute stretch that included eight straight misses from the field. ''We have to give it up to him. We tried to wear him out and have different players guarding him, and it didn't happen,'' Brian Cook said of Domercant. ''He's a great shooter.'' Cook scored 21 points and Roger Powell added 16 for the Illini. Luther Head replaced freshman Deron Williams in the starting lineup for Illinois. Williams sprained his ankle in practice Sunday, and was limited to just 15 minutes averaging 26 minutes in the first five games of the season. Jesse Mackinson added 12 points for the Panthers.
